Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Athens. Unattributed. Ca. 500.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: to right of Thetis' right leg: Πε̣λευς. Ext.: to Astyanax' left: [Αστ]υανα[χ]ς. Below hands of Helen: [hελεν]ε vac. Near the archer: [Τευκρ]ος{1}. Above shield and helmet in the last fr.: [---]ρα[---]{2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Frs. a - c.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Graef–Langlotz does not restore; not in the dr. {2} not properly drawn in Graef–Langlotz, who suggests: [---εγ]ρα[φσεν](?). Beazley does not list this.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: BADB 7930 (bibl.). — Tsountas (1885a), pl. 5, fig. 3. — Richards (1894), 186-191, pl. 2 (dr.). — Graef–Langlotz (1925–33), ii, no. 212, pl. 10 dr.). — Davreux (1942), 170/112. — Wienke (1954), pl. 62, fig. 28 (dr.). — Ghali-Kahil (1955), 75/39. — Clement (1958), 63 and nn. 89-90. — LIMC ii (1984), pl. 684, Astyanax I/17 (part of A). — LIMC iv (1988), pl. 332, Helene 228.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fragmentary RF cup. Unattributed. First quarter fifth. 490-480 (CVA).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: part of a winged figure (goddess?). Ext.: A-B: komos.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: to right of the figure, at mid-height, along the margin: καλος. Ext.: fr. PD 277: hο παις. PD 283: [κα]λος. PD 284: [--]γα[--]{1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Florence PD 277, 283, 284. + other frs.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} I wonder if the gamma is not a pi: (π)α[ις]?
Record.AVI-Bibliography: A. Magi, CVA Florence 4, Italy 38 (1964), pl. 120,1-5 (no. bibl.).

Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Unattributed{1}. Third quarter fifth. Ca. 440 (Ure).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: maeander. Ext.: part of a woman dancer and of a male leaning on his stick, watching her. Legs of a draped male with his stick. Palmette.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Ext.: on the fr. with the dancer, in white: Σ[--]{2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Three non-joining frs. The sigma shaped = `3' reversed.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Beazley apud CVA: late work in the Penthesilean tradition. {2} U. says that near the right edge there is a drooping lotus; this makes me think that the fr. preserves the right edge of the scene and I wonder if there is room for a name beginning with the sigma. The inscription could also be: [--]^σ[--], with the figure of the watcher intervening.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: P.N. Ure and A.D. Ure, CVA Reading 1, Great Britain 12 (1954), pl. 24, ... (no bibl.).

Record.CAVI-Comments: No S. number; no Bareiss number. Not previously published.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} surely nonsense inaccurately rendered. Printed in text mostly in the Attic alphabet. First letter: Ionic gamma (perhaps intended by the author for pi as is sometimes done); second letter: three-stroke sigma; third: Attic lambda leaning back somewhat; then a slash; then a break; finally two rather odd Attic lambdas (meant for upsilons?). The photo., pl. 408,3, shows only one indistinct letter
Record.AVI-Bibliography: M.B. Moore, CVA Malibu 8, USA 33 (1998), no. 36, pl. 408,2-4.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: RF cup. From Chiusi. Manner of Epeleios Painter (CVA). Ca. 510-500 (CVA).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: fragmentary: a warrior to right, mostly missing. A-B: battles: A: six figures on foot. B: two horsemen to right, pursuing two hoplites.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: on the warrior's left, curving downward: κα[λος], retr.; on his right, starting at the head, curving downward: hο π[α]ις. A: between the figures, at head height: [h]ο π^αις ^ καλο^ς. B: similar: [h]ο π^αις ^ κα[λ]ος.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Attic alphabet.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: M. Sipsie-Eschbach, CVA Giessen 1, Germany 70 (1998), pls. 39,3-4, and 40,1-2; sketches with inscriptions on pp. 56-57; Beilage 8,3 (profile) (bibl.). [[Lipsie]]

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Unattributed. Last quarter sixth. 510-500 (Weiss).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Ext.: fr. a: part of an animal's back. Fr. b: two animal legs. Fr. c: animal tail(?) and part of a palmette(?).
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Ext.: fr. a: above the animal: [--]γ(.)[--]{1}. Fr. b: to right of the left leg: [--]λ(ε)[--]{2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Frs. a - c.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Attic gamma. Bottom of a left diagonal line as of an alpha. {2} Attic lambda. Epsilon with two horizontals only. Weiss reads this as part of a kalos-inscription, perhaps reading the epsilon as an open and somewhat angular omicron, which is possible: [--- κα]λο[ς](?).
Record.AVI-Bibliography: C. Weiss, CVA Karlsruhe 3, Germany 60 (1990), pl. 29,5-7, figs. 17,a-b (drs. of Ext. of frs. a and b) (no bibl.).

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fragmentary RF cup. Douris. Kleophrades, potter. First quarter fifth. Ca. 490 (GMusJ).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: Departure of Triptolemos with Eros present. In the zone: chariot race. A: Achilles and Troilos. B: battle with Athena present, perhaps Achilles and Hector.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: above Triptolemos: [Τ]ριπ{π}τολ[εμ]ος, retr. At right, next to a wing: Ερ[ος]. Behind the chariot: [εγ]ρα[φσεν], retr.{1}. Under the handle B/A: Φαιδριας{2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + numerous other frs. at Malibu. For the connection of Malibu 87.AE.43 and 90.AE.36, see B.-O. 60-61. R. Guy suggests that some frs. may be from a replica, to which a fr. with the inscription [Δει]φοβος may belong. Phaidrias occurs on Louvre C 10,917+ and perhaps the fr. Leipzig T 3637; see ARV[2] 1605. The attribution to Kleophrades is based on the similarity with the signed Douris cup Berlin 2283.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} this should be a Douris signature; the name is lost. {2} B.-O. thinks this may be from a potter's signature. I rather think it is a kalos-name, the kalos being lost (see above).
Record.AVI-Bibliography: True (1991), 139/17 (not ill.; the 88 new frs. only). — Buitron-Oliver (1995), 17, 60-61, 75/36, pls. 147-48.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Douris. First quarter fifth. Ca. 490 (GMusJ).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: bearded man seated to left; fr. 81.AE.192.1 gives a bit of his folding stool(1); at upper left, remains probably of greaves hung up. A: warriors arming.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: in field: a three-stroke sigma{2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Cut in antiquity to make a stemmed plate. - + 82.AE.146.19. + 81.AE.192.1 (All join(3)). + 82.AE.146.9 + 83.AE.35 + 85.AE.448 + 87.AE.153 + 89.AE.37. The above description is only of 83.AE.35. Three-stroke sigma.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} GettyMusJ says: Thetis and Hephaestus. Buitron does not identify the (single) figure. {2} there is ample space on the left between the greave and the sigma, and somewhat less space to the sigma's right. Hence I cannot decide between: [--]ς, [--]σ[--], and Σ[--]. {3} so my note from the GettyMusJ, but Buitron (who knows of only 3 frs.) says that 82.AE.146.19 and 83.AE.35 join, while the small fr. 81.AE.192.1 is separate.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Athens. Unattributed{1}. Last quarter sixth. Ca. 510-500.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Battle (from Trojan War?): head of a warrior with bleeding eyes; foot of another; legs, shield lance, of two others.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: To right of warrior's helmet: σ[---]{2}. Below the shield: Απ[---]{3}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Frs. a - e.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Langlotz attributes to late Oltos; not listed in Beazley. {2} Graef–Langlotz gives εσι, but the dr. shows only the sigma. εσι could be from a name such as [Προτ]εσι[λαος]. {3} Graef–Langlotz reads ΠΑ[---], retr. Hence either Απ[ολ[λ]λον], or Πα[τροκλος]?

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Athens. Euphronios. Last quarter sixth. 510-500 (so also Stasinopoulou-Kakarouga in `Euphronios'). Very late (Robertson).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int: part of (male?) head. A-B: wedding of Peleus and Thetis.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A: to left of Thetis' mouth,: Θετις, retr. Between two women at the right, in slightly larger letters: [Ευφρον]ιος εγραφσεν, retr.{1}. Under one handle: Λεαγ[ρος] καλος. On B: to right of Hera's head: h[ερα]{2}. To upper right of head:hεφαιστος, retr.{3}. [?καλο]ς, Λε[αγρος]. `Euphronios '191 has quite different readings: A: Θετις, retr. as above. Seated figure: hεφαιστος. Signature wrongly rendered: [Ευφρον]ιος [not retr.] εγραφσεν [upside down]. B: no mention of the heta with Hera. A letter mentioned but not named, for Artemis. Walking: Leto: letters Λε[το]. A doe and inscription Λεα[γρος] καλος.
Record.CAVI-Comments: = N.M. 15,214. Many frs. added, from Chicago University, Schliemann, H. Seyrig, M. Robertson (ARV[2]). The fr. with Hephaestus from a photo. - Robertson: one of two latest works (the other the Arezzo krater). - Philippaki suggests (65) that Leto, Artemis and Apollo were shown as a family group. Sigmas are turned in retr. There may be more inscriptions; see the bibl. in ARV[2] and Add.[2]. - Phi is of the bun type, once with slanting vertical.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} -εν over the design and border. The whole inscription is retr., pace `Euphr.'; see photo, p. 193. The signature may show a part of the nu before --]ιος, but there is some damage. {2} the h of Hera is to right of her back of head, horizontal. {3} to left of H.'s forehead, horizontal but curving at end as it runs into Athena's helmet: hεφαισ^τος, retr. Athena's spear intervenes. The Chicago fr.: Art Bulletin 21 (1926) fig. 7: stag, probably under a handle; remains of inscription Λεαγρος καλος.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Photo (Hephaestus fr.). — Wolters (1888a), 104-105, n. 1 (dr., Schliemann fr. with Hephaestus). — Graef–Langlotz (1925–33), ii, no. 176, pl. 8 (part). — Luschey (1938), 762, [[767]] fig. 3 (same fr.). — Svatik (1939), fig. 7 (Chicago fr.). — ARV[2] (1963), 17/18 (bibl.). — Philippaki (1974), 72, figs. 30 and 31, below (Ext., parts) (exc. colored picture). — Philippaki (1980), Chronika 62-65 (A). — Add.[2] (1989), 153 (bibl.). — Shapiro (1989), 56, pl. 26,d. — AttScr (1990), 65 n. 26 [[mention]]. — Stasinopoulou-Kakarouga (1990), 207/44. — Robertson (1992), 44.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Manner of Euphronios{1}; Onesimos (Williams). Euphronios, potter (?). Early fifth. 500-490. Very early (Williams).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: Neoptolemos slaying Priam on an altar, using Astyanax as a weapon; Hecuba; a dead body on the ground. Ext.: Iliupersis: Greeks pursuing women.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: N.'s shield device: lion, above which, in BG: καλος. On the altar in BG: Διος | hιερο[ν] | [τεμε]νος, the last word retr. [So Williams]. Below Astyochos' head: Αστυοχ[ο]ς{3}. In the exergue: Ευ[φ]ρ̣ον[ιος εποιεσεν]{4}. B: to right of a warrior's head: [Οδυσσ]ευς. A or B: W. says that the names of Diomedes (where?), Teukros (A), i.e., Τ̣ευκρ̣[ος], and Odysseus (B) can be made out. I thought it best to keep in addition the fragmentary letter groups I give in AttScr: --]ον. --]θο[--. B: --]ευς. An unplaced fragment has: --]δε[--.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Rome, Vatican{2}. The Berlin frs. lost in the war, except for one handle fr. [--]νος could be the fallen warrior's name. Williams says the earliest work by Onesimos (Panaitios Painter). - Anderson says the woman on the Int. is Polyxena, not inscribed. [She is Polyxena on Malibu 83.AE.362, inscribed.] On p. 131 n. 6 A. suggests that Daiphonos [on the Malibu cup] is for Onesimos an alternative for Daiphobos. Hence he suggests (against Williams): Διος hιερο[ν], and separately [Δαιφο]νος for the fallen warrior on the Int.; it is written retr. because it originated from the warrior's head.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Furtwängler (1885), nos. 2280, 2281. — Stenico (1953), 497ff., pls. 1-2 (Vatican frs.). — Speier (1954), 113ff., pls. 21-26. — ARV[2] (1963), 19/1 and 2 (joining){2}. — D. Williams (1976), 13-15, figs. 3-7. — Add.[2] (1989), 153. — AttScr (1990), no. 418. — D. Williams (1990), 33 and 35, fig. 1 (restored dr.; upside down). — Robertson (1992), 44 and 45. — Anderson (1995), 131 n. 15.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fragmentary RF cup. From Athens, Agora E 14:5. Recalls Euphronios{1}. Last quarter sixth. Ca. 510-500 (Moore).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: man or youth courting a boy{2}.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: On the BG offset rim, in purple: Αγασικ[ρ]ατ̣[ες] : καλ̣[ο]ς{3}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Type C. Inscription in red. Large `ornamental' letters.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} compared by Beazley with a WG/RF cup in Gotha (ARV[2] 20) which shows the influence of artists like Euphronios and the Sosias Painter; the Agora cup recalls Euphronios. {2} Mostly missing. {3} there is an excess of space in both bracketed areas, which I cannot explain.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Photo. — Beazley (1947), 221[[f.]]/γ 15. — Stamires–Vanderpool (1950), 381 and n. 22. — H.A. Thompson (1958), 157 and n. 21, pl. 45,c. — ARV[2] (1963), 20, 1559. — Dover (1978), 122/R 31. — Kilmer (1993), cat. R 31. — Moore (1997), 340/1556, pls. 146-47 (147 shows most of inscription).

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Euthymides. Last quarter sixth. 510-500. Early (Robertson).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Ext.: deities on Olympus, probably Birth of Athena.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: [Ευ]θυμιδες | εγραφσεν{1}. Below the signature: [Α]πολ[λ]ο[ν]ος. hιλυθυα. Poseidon is also inscribed.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + New York 1977.192.2a-d; + Florence 7 B 2 (part ex Villa Giulia), three frs.; Boston 10.203; London 1952.12-2.7; Vatican, Astarita 121, two frs. There are now more frs. and the cup cannot be fully discussed until it is reconstructed and published, although Dr. von Bothmer has kindly given me some information. Add.[2] reports that the London and Astarita frs. are at present on loan in New York.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Add.[2] has [Ευ]θυμι[δες] εγρα[φσεν].

Inscriptions.Inscription: DEUS, PHOR[PHYRION], APOLLOON, EURYALOS, [EU]RYBOTOS, HEPH[AISTOS], ECHSOR

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Athens. Euthymides. Last quarter sixth. 510-500.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int: (garment). A-B: Gigantomachy.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int: [Λε]αγρο[ς ---]. A-B: above Zeus' head: Δευς, for Ζευς; so listed in Threatte (1996). To right of a giant's face: Φορ[φυριον]. To left of Apollo, above a giant's shield: Απολλ{ο}ον, retr. To left of a giant's face: Ευρυαλο[ς], retr. Between an outstretched giant and Poseidon: [Ευ]ρ̣υβοτος? To Hephaestus' left, at height of forehead: hεφ[αιστος], retr. Above a helmet and lance: Εχσορ{1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Frs. a.–g. Graef–Langlotz gives the alpha of Leagros as extant. Graef–Langlotz's text has Φρο[--, but the phot. seems to show Φορ[--. Eurybotos: ελυβοτ, Graef–Langlotz; --λυβοτ--, Eph 1886, pl. 9,2; [Πο]λυβοτ[ες], RE, i.e., Πολυβωτης; the photo in Graef–Langlotz shows no letter before lambda, and this letter looks more like a D-shaped rho. Small and hasty letters.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} see Peek: a new giant name.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: RE suppl. 3 (1918), col. 646/11 [[rather somewhere 655ff., s.v. Giganten (Waser)]]. — Graef–Langlotz (1925–33), ii, pl. 10 (A-B); Peek, ibid., 130. — ARV[2] (1963), 29/20. — AttScr (1990), no. 383. — Threatte (1996), 231.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of eye cup (BF/RF?){1}. Epiktetos. Last quarter sixth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: CVA: Int.: 2 small isolated frs. are extant: BF: feet of a horse to right (Villard says: a horseman [no doubt rightly as the horse is raising its front feet.](2) Ext.: between eyes: A: a youth trying to lift(?) a large column krater. B: a nose.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: along the left margin: Επικτε[--]. Near the right margin: [--]σεν{3}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Beazley thinks these frs. may be from the same cup as C 10,458 (the other part), ARV[2] 71/11, but he treats the sets as separate.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} these frs. are listed in ARV[2] 46/121, in his `Interlude', among cups where one cannot tell whether they were bilingual or RF, as the Int. is not extant. However, 71/10 has only an Int., which is BF, and 71/11 (cf. 43/60) which has only a RF Ext., may be from the same cup, which would clearly be bilingual. CVA published both sets under the same number as one cup. {2} ARV[2] 71/10 says: Int.: BF: fawn, which does not agree with CVA, although the inscription does. {3} So Villard who restores [εγραφ]σεν. But the first preserved letter may show as an incomplete circle, whence [εγρασ]φ̣εν is perhaps likely. [The ph. is small, so I cannot be sure.] ARV[2] has [εγρασ]φεν.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: F. Villard, CVA Louvre 10, France 17 (1951), pl. 8,2-5 (figs. 2-3 are of Int.). — Bothmer (1955), 68 (1 new fr.). — ARV[2] (1963), 46/121 and *71/10.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fragmentary RF cup. Oltos. Cachrylion, potter. Last quarter sixth. Early (Beazley).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: Pegasus. A: maenad between two satyrs. B: komos: flute girl between two youths.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: [Χαχ]ρ[υλι]ον εποιει.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Heidelberg 5 [[no inscr.]] + Braunschweig 537 [[not in CAVI]] + Baltimore (Johns Hopkins, ex Arch. Society). + Bowdoin 1913.14. Part ex Villa Giulia. - Note the spelling of εποιει in -ει.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Frs. illustrated in CVA: pls. 1, 21, 33; 3, 6-8; 12, 96. All frs., pl. X in CF.

Robinson, CVA Robinson 2, USA 6 (1937), pl. 1,1 (Baltimore fr.). — A. Greifenhagen, CVA Braunschweig, Germany 4 (1940), pl. 12,2 (Braunschweig fr.). — ARV[2] (1963), 59/55. — R. Williams (1984), 138-39 (Baltimore fr. and reconstruction). — Add.[2] (1989), 164.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Oltos. Last quarter sixth. Still early (Beazley).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: flute girl. A: heroes quarreling. B: komos of three males.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A: Μεμνον κ[α]λος. B: one komast: Ευαγορα[ς]{2}. Near a lyre player, above a psykter standing in a krater: Αντα̣νδρο[ς]{3}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Florence frs. + Villa Giulia. + Chicago, University 1967.115.64. See also ARV[2] 59/59, which might belong, but is entered here as Florence [no no.].

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fragmentary RF cup. Oltos. Cachrylion, potter. Last quarter sixth. Early middle (Beazley).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: an archer. A: duel, with a horseman. B: a satyr and a maenad with a donkey.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: Χαχρυλ[ι]ον and [εποι]εσε(ν), the last retr. Θρ[ασ]ε(ς), for Θρασεας{1}. A: Θρασες. [--]ας and below it: [κα]λος{2}. B: the maenad: Θαλια.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + a fr. ex Florence. + Vatican, Astarita 298. The inscriptions after CF, and, for the Astarita fr., ARV[2].
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Θρ[--]ες shares the sigma with the nu of [--]εσεν. {2} the last two words on A are on the Astarita fr. In CF, Beazley (the Astarita fr. not yet included) also reads [--]ος; thus there are perhaps two names and a kalos-name on A, unless [--]ος is another kalos.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: D. Levi, CVA Florence 1, Italy 8 (1932), pl. 1 B 51 (part). — CF (1933), .... — ARV[2] (1963), 59/60.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Athens. Oltos. Last quarter sixth. Ca. 520-510. Still early (Beazley).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: warrior and youth. A: Adrastos mounting his chariot.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A: fr. a: Α{:}δρ[αστος], retr. Fr. c: to right of two remaining feet: [---]ι̣ο̣ς, retr. A or B: fr. d: [Μ]εμμ[νον ---].
Record.CAVI-Comments: Frs. a - d + Acr. 52 and perhaps 119 (see ARV[2] 1622: recalls Oltos). "A fr. added by Mrs. Karouzou completes the head of the youth on I (BCH 1952, 203, a)," ARV[2] 60 [This should be a third fr. in addition to the two numbered frs.].

Record.CAVI-Lemma: RF cup. From Chiusi (C. Smith). Oltos. Last quarter sixth. Not early.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: trumpeter. A: lion and lioness attacking a bull. B: lion and lioness (or two lions) attacking a fawn.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: [--- ε]ποιεσ[εν]{1}. A: above the scene: [---] ε(μ)οι δ(ο)κ(α)ς{2}. B: h[ο πα]ι[ς ---](?){1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Florence; Villa Giulia; Vatican, Astarita 299.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Beazley. {2} this inscription is given by C. Smith, who suggests [καλος(?)] εμοι δοκᾳς or δοκεις. But the lettering he prints is odd: mu is turned 90 degrees, delta has a vertical stroke, the omicron is dotted and alpha lacks the righthand point; sigma is three-stroke and reversed.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Hartwig (1894), 155 (E 1). — C.H. Smith in BM Cat. E (1896), 41. — D. Levi, CVA Florence 1, Italy 8 (1932), pl. 3 B 4 (part). — ARV[2] (1963), 60/65.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Athens. Epiktetos. Last quarter sixth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: A: Heracles and the lion, with Iolaus.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A: Ε[πικτε]τος{1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Frs. a - b. Kraiker suggests that Acr. 65 may belong with Acr. 62 and Beazley agrees.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} so ARV[2] 73/26; Graef–Langlotz prints [Επικ]τετος, which is wrong; Kraiker has Ε...τετος, which is slightly better; the photo shows: fr. a: [--](.)Ε̣..., and fr. b: [--](.)ος (the first bracketed `letter' is a short upright stroke, probably not a real letter); Beazley's reading is clearly the best.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fr. of RF cup. Oltos. Last quarter sixth. Later (Beazley).
Record.CAVI-Subject: A: fight{1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + 1 B 57. - Beazley refers to the same name on Athens, Ceramicus, BF fr., JdI 61-62, pl. 17,59. See also IG i/2. 975 = i/3. 1210, and DAA, no. 186 (ca. 500 B.C.). It seems to me that this ought to be a kalos-name, although Beazley does not list it as such. See also LGPN ii.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} probably Heracles and Cycnus, cf. London E 88, ARV[2] 63/88, also by Oltos (Beazley). {2} [?Γ]ναθον ..., Beazley.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Oltos. Last quarter sixth. Later (Beazley).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: a nude man running. A: Heracles and Nessos; at right, Deianeira. B: satyr, maenad, donkey.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: nonsense: at left: κρετν[--]. At right: [--]οσεν. A: [---]χ[---]. [hε]ρακ[λες]. Δαιανειρα{2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + 1 B 53; + 5, 1 and 8; others in Florence and Villa Giulia.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} unclear where this is listed in ARV[2]: the index refers to Florence 1 B 52; under that number the index has: 1 B 52-53: [p.] 65. ARV[2] (1963), 65/106 is however listed as Villa Giulia (part ex Florence) and Heidelberg 4, and gives (for Florence) only 1 B 52. The subjects are: A: satyr, maenad, and B: satyrs. This does not correspond to the description in CVA, for which see above. {2} sic. All readings from the text of CF.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: D. Levi, CVA Florence 1, Italy 8 (1932), pl. 1, B 36, etc. — CF (1933), 8/1.36 and 53{1}.

Record.CAVI-Subject: Remains of seven figures: A: athletes and youths. B: komos{1}.

Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: around the tondo: hο πα[ις καλος](?). A: near the lip: [hο] π[α]ις, ναι̣{1}. B: near the lip: [h]ο παις, ναι.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Cup type B.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} there is a trace of the final iota above the handle palmette.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Euergides Painter. Last quarter sixth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: komast: a youth with a drinking horn, running. A-B: komos.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: in a circle around the figure, facing him: h(ο) (π)^α[ι]ς (κ)αλος. Ext.: one fr., once in the [Italian] market shows the upper part of the head of a youth and a piece of his arm(?) and: h[---]{2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Oxford 1927.4075, 1953.1 and 1953.642 (gift of Bothmer) + Italian market. The writing looks like a copy made by an illiterate: the first omicron (only partially preserved) is a sharp hook; kappa resembles a triangular rho. But the Faina portion of the cup is very much restored; are all letters genuine?
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} three frs. formerly in the Italian market, of which two are Oxford 1953.1. {2} my note from a ph. shows a standed laver, on the bowl of which, in BG, well spaced: καλος. This is fr. g in CVA: two youths filling a laver from two pointed amphoras.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Vulci. Unattributed. Cachrylion, potter. Last quarter sixth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: satyr. A: Death of Aegisthus. B: fight.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: Χαχρυλιον εποιεσεν. A: Λεαγρος [κα]λος. B: [Λεαγ]ρος καλος, retr.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Roman Market (Basseggio; lost). + Cab. Med. (ex Fröhner). + ex Villa Giulia frs. The dr. shows the cup very much restored. Hauser, FR ii, 79 n.2 denied that the subject was the death of Aegisthus; see E.T. Vermeule (1966), 15/10.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: WV (1869–91), F, pl. 1 (dr. of Roman Mkt fr.). — D. Levi, CVA Florence 1, Italy 8 (1932), pl. 4. — CF (1933), pl. 4 B 19 and 42; pl. 6 B 23; pl. 12 B 13 and 43. — ARV[2] (1963), 108/29. — Add.[2] (1989), 173.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fr. of RF cup. From Athens. Unattributed{1}. Late sixth (vase); early fifth (Gr.). Ca. 510 (Moore: the pot).
Record.CAVI-Subject: A: athletes (boxers?) (Moore). Fr. a: upper part of youth running to right and seen from back.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: On the inside of fr. a (written on the sherd) , Gr.: παι, τοι Φαλα[νθοι] / αλ[λ]ος κα[ι]νος κλ[ιντερ]/ας φορει.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Five frs. Coral red used. From rectangular rock-cut shaft. For its date and the date of its potttery, see Shear Jr (1993), 383ff., deposit summary, pp. 445-49. The restoration of the inscription is uncertain. Note the Ionic alphabet at this early date. The inscription was written on the sherd and is dated by context. For κα[ι]νος see Threatte (1980), 269. Threatte (1996), 512 discusses ει for ε.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} for attribution (or parallels) see Moore.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Apollodoros. First quarter fifth. Ca. 490-480 (CVA).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: warrior coming to the rescue (stalking). A: warriors fighting (parts of three). B: warriors coming up to join (as on the Int.; βοηθοι: two preserved).
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: on the rim of the shield, in BG: [καλ]ε, ναι{1}. To left of warrior's helmet [Ευρυπτολ]εμ[ος...{2}. A: on the rim of a shield: [κ]αλ[--]{3}. B: To left and right of the left warrior's head: [Απολλ]οδορος v. εγρ^α(φ)σεν. On his shield: h[---]ι[--]{4}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Ex Castle Ashby. + Villa Giulia (Apollodoros). - Beazley connected the Castle Ashby fr. with frs. in Villa Giulia; it is part of B, reinforcements coming up to the fight on A. Beazley says a fallen warrior on A is male, but for the rest one cannot tell whether the warriors are Greeks or Amazons. - Furtwängler wrongly connected this Castle Ashby fr. with ARV[2] 371/16, now listed as Geneva Market, which he attributed to the Brygos Painter, thus assuming [--]οδορος was the name of the Brygos Painter; Hartwig, disproving this, restored Apollodoros after Louvre [G 139-140, ARV[2] 120/1]. - Tailed rho. Three-snd four-stroke sigma. Phi = cartwheel theta.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} referring to the shield. {2} "no doubt," Beazley (1933); I am not sure that there is room to the right of the head for a καλος; it may have been somewhere else. Euryptolemos is a kalos-name confined to Apollodoros (ARV[2] 1580). {3} could be καλ[ε --] again. {4} Hartwig read the heta; the iota is on a VG fr. Beazley (who did not look for the heta) thinks it may be the beginning of h[ο or h[ε πα]ι[ς]; but there is not enough space, if his reconstruction is right: perhaps (κ)[αλε, να]ι, as on the Int.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: S. Birch apud Gerhard (1846), 342/11. — Conze (1864a), 237. — Furtwängler (1881a), 302f. — Hartwig (1893), 314, 628-30, 690/1, pl. 69,1 (BC). — Beazley (1929b), 19/27. — Beazley (1933), 69-70, pl. 6 (6.1, dr. of BC Ext. after Hartwig; 6,2-5, photos of VG frs.). — CF (1933), app. no. 14. — Philippart (1935), 213, par. 3/1. — ARV[2] (1963), 120/4. — J. Boardman and M. Robertson, CVA Northampton, Castle Ashby, Great Britain 15 (1979), no. 64, pl. 41,2. — Add.[2] (1989), 175. — AttScr (1990), no. 1103.

Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A: along top margin: hο παι[ς κ]αλος{1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Florence fr. (part ex Villa Giulia). Amsterdam fr.: ex Hauser, Arndt (no. 8151) and The Hague, Scheurleer collections. The Heidelberg fr. is in Amsterdam, the Florence fr. not (as of 1988).

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of small RF cup (AMA Group). Skythes (?). Amasis, potter (?). Third quarter sixth. Ca. 530.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: Head and foot of a satyr, dancing.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Starting to right of head and continuing to left of foot, up and down, in orange approximating incision or reserved (Cohen): Αμα[---] and ε[---]{1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: New frs. added prove the existence of the potter's signature of Amasis and an attribution to Skythes; see Mertens. Hence not all vases potted by Amasis are by the Amasis Painter (Isler). It is clear that the potter Amasis worked for RF at end of his career. - Moore (1997), 80 n. 8: ref. to Mertens in Papers ... (1987) 173-75: she discusses 2 fragmentary cups in Florence from the AMA Group and 2 frs. in the Cahn collection, Cahn 696 and 695. [The Florence frs. are: the present vase and A, B 1, the first RF, the second bilingual. The second is uninscribed.] Cahn att. his frs. to Skythes; the inscriptions are: 696: ]μασις. 695: [--]ς εποιει. Mertens accepts the attribution and thinks Florence A, B 1 [which Beazley says is near Florence 1 B 6 which he thinks probably has the sig. of Amasis] may also be by Skythes.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Αμα[σις(?)] | ε[ποιεσεν(?)], Beazley. But see now Mertens. On the question of the style, see AttScr.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fragmentary RF cup. Paseas (Cerberus Painter). Last quarter sixth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: a woman, running and carrying on her left arm a phallus-bird kissing her lips. A: Heracles and Geryon. B: unexplained: Artemis and males (fragmentary).
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: below the left arm: ει κ̣[αλε](?){1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Heidelberg 20 [[no inscr.]]. + ex Florence 1 B 8-9; 25-26 B 40; 6 B 29; 11 B 65; 12 B 37; 20 B 55.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} this follows a suggestion by Beazley in CF. I wonder if something (a name?) did not precede these words. Usually εἶ is not found at the beginning of a kalos statement, but see London E 398, RF pelike, unattributed, BSA 29 (1929-28) 197-98, which has ει σφοδρα καλη. Louvre G 136, RF cup, Eucharides Painter, ARV[2] 231/78, has: ει συ κα[λος] and Αριστειδες, which can be read before or after the kalos statement.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Photo (Int.). — Kraiker (1931), pl. 4 (Heidelberg fr.). — D. Levi, CVA Florence 1, Italy 8 (1932), III I, pl. 1 B 8-9 (part), etc. — CF (1933), pl. Y, 1 (Int.). — ARV[2] (1963), 163/10.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Tarquinia. Kleophrades Painter. Ca. 500. Early (Beazley).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: a young warrior putting on his greaves. A-B: Heracles and the Amazons.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: to the warrior's upper left: καλ[--], retr. To his upper right: καλ[--], retr. To right and left of his shin: [--]εσ[--]{1}. Higher up, to right of a lance: [--]σ[--]{1}. A: καλο̣[ς], retr.? Χσανθιππ[ε]. hε[ρα]κλεες{2}. [Ανδρο]μα[χε]. [--]υσ[--]. [--]α[--]. [--]ομ[--]. On the reserved foot profile, in BG: Κλεοφραδες :* εποιεσεν :* Αμασ[ιδος hυυ]ς :*{3}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + 699 and other frs. Four-stroke sigma in the signature only. Robertson gives the history of Hartwig's attribution of the signature to a younger Amasis. Robertson 84 says that this and no. 536+ are a pair of cups, one of which is inscribed with Kleophrades' signature, just like the pair by Douris, Berlin 2283 and 2284.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} so Beazley (1933a). [699 has a sigma, according to de Ridder.] {2} so Bothmer; Beazley has hε[ρα]κλεε[ς]. {3} Beazley notes (as had Six) that exactly seven letters are missing. The last letter is fragmentary, but a certain sigma. The above reading is Bothmer's in GettyJ. Earlier readings are: Κλεοφραδες εποιεσεν. Αμασ[ις εγραφσε] or [εγραφ]σ[ε] Gerhard, revived by Hartwig. Αμασ[ις καλο]ς, O. Jahn, revived by Klein. Αμασ.......ς, Beazley, although he preferred Six' reading to Jahn's. Six read: Αμασ[ιος hυυ]ς. Bothmer has now shown that the genitive should be in -ιδος. See further his article in JPaulGettyJ.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF/WG cup. From Athens. Manner of Onesimos (Panaitios Painter) (but see below!). Euphronios, potter. Early fifth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int., WG: Athena to left pouring libation; owl at left. Ext., RF: A: fr. a: seated man to left with phiale and spear. B: fr. c: hand of male holding kantharos to left, offering a libation.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: in zone outside of picture: [Ευφρο]νι[ο]ς εποιεσεν{1}. A: fr. a: to left of man's open mouth: Ζεῦ Σο̃τερ, retr.{2}. At left: κυι̣(3) and below, the first letter of another word. B: fr. c: above and to right of hand holding kantharos (clearly issuing from the lost mouth), horizontal and eventually bending down sharply: σπένδο̅ το̃ι Δαίμονι το̃ι Ἀγαθ[ο̃ι]{4}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Frs. a - c + a lost piece. See Graef–Langlotz's discussion of the libations. Long discussion and bibl. in D(elight) Tolles, The Banquet Libations of the Greeks (Bryn Mawr diss. 1943) 61-62. She thinks the Agathos Daimon is = Zeus Soter. Cf. also ibid. 70 n. 119. - Williams (1991), ...., n. 16 (listing), attributes to the Antiphon Painter.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Photo. — Benndorf (1868–83), pl. 29,1 (incomplete, but with the lost piece). — Richards (1894), 383 (Ext.). — Graef–Langlotz (1925–33), ii, no. 434, pl. 33 (Ext.) and 35 (Int., dr.). — ARV[2] (1963), 330/5, 333, 1646. — Mertens (1974), 99, figs. 16-17 (all). — Mertens (1977), pl. 27,2 (Int.). — Wehgartner (1983), pl. 17,1-2 (all). — Add.[2] (1989), 217. — Lissarrague (1990b), 205 n. 55.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Onesimos. Euphronios, potter (?). First quarter fifth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: a warrior? (Part of a shield and cloak){2}. A-B: Ajax and Tekmessa; Ajax' slaughter of the cattle{3}.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: [Ευφρονιος εποι]εσεν{4}. A or B: Williams (1980): [Αγαμεμνο]ν(?) Ευ[--]. [Ευφρο]νι[ιος εποιεσεν](?)(5) (But see below).
Record.CAVI-Comments: 2 frs. + C 11,336 (1 fr., q.v.; the pertinence is uncertain; see below). + New York 1977.192.3 (part ex Louvre C 11,342 (ARV[2] 327/97, Add.[2] (1989), 216); part ex Oxford, Private. + New York, Bothmer (2 frs.). Williams' restorations are attractive since a painter's signature is unlikely (Onesimos' signature occurs only once, on Louvre G 105).
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} erroneous interpretation as an athletic scene. {2} Williams (1980: 139) suggests perhaps the armor of Achilles given to Neoptolemos as on the Douris cup, Vienna 3695. {3} so Williams (1980), q.v. for details of the very scanty frs. Beazley had suggested the Deeds of Theseus, with a query. {4} So CB; not restored in ARV[2]. {5} Williams rejects the possible alternative: [---]ν vacat Ευ[φρο]νι[ος εποιεσεν], on the grounds that Ευ[-- is too close to the handle to be part of a potter's signature. He thus suggests heroic names; for Ευ[--: Ευ[ρυπυλος] or Ευρυσακης (although he would be too young). --]νι[-- might be [Τελαμο]νι[ος], but is more likely from a signature. However, in GVGettyMus he says that that fr. (C 11,336) does not belong. AK, pl. 33,3 shows νι, pl. 33,4 shows --]ν vacat Ευ[--. The first nu has the typical Euphronian shape (see Euphronios und seine Zeit (1992) 52): does this mean that this fr. is from a vase painted by Euphronios?
Record.AVI-Bibliography: CB (1931–63), ii, 30 (not ill.). — ARV[2] (1963), 319/4 and 327/97. — D. Williams (1976a), pl. 4,c (Louvre and Oxford parts){1}. — D. Williams (1980), 137ff., pl. 33,1-6. — Sparkes (1985), 38 n. 72 (notes a handle fr.). — Add.[2] (1989), 214 and 216. — D. Williams (1991), ....

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Orvieto. Eleusis Painter{1}. Late sixth. 510-500 (CVA). Early (Beazley).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: a woman(?) running. Ext.: Iliupersis: A or B: Astyanax upside down, held by Neoptolemos (little remains of him), also the head and raised arm of a woman; the head of Ajax and Cassandra at the Palladion (the lower part remains), also part of a shield and spear; a pair of arms, behind which is part of a shield{2}.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A or B: on the Astyanax fr.: καλος{3}. On the Cassandra fr.: Λεα[γρος]. On the fr. with two arms: above the arms: καλο[ς]. On the shield (on the fr. with arms), in BG: κ[αλος](?).
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Vienna University 53c23-25. Beazley added CVA, pl. 10,3 and 5.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} connected with the Proto-Panaitian Group. {2} the description is taken from CVA; the distribution of the frs. is unclear. {3} may be with sideways sigma, if ARV[2] can be trusted.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Patsch (1891), 181/13. — L. Laurinsich, CVA Bologna 1, Italy 5 (1929), III I, pl. 10,1-4, 7 (also 5: see below). — ARV[2] (1963), 314/1. — Add.[2] (1989), 213.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of WG cup. From Eleusis. Eleusis Painter (Beazley{1}); Onesimos (D. Williams). Ca. 500.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: Triton: head and upper body; at upper right, dolphin.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: to left of Triton's face, in BG: [--]ος. Under his right arm pit: Θ[--].
Record.CAVI-Comments: On p. 55 Robertson gives the history of the attributions of Eleusis 618 and 619: Karouzou: Euphronios. Beazley: Eleusis Painter (includes RF). D. Williams: very early Onesimos (Panaitios Painter): grouped with the Berlin/Vatican Ilioupersis cup. The reff. are in n. 70. Cartwheel theta. (1 or 2 in chart in AttScr).(2)
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} connected with the Proto-Panaitian Group. {2} depending on how the sherd is poised. ARV[2], prints cartwheel theta and Robertson shows this too, as does the photo.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: RF cup. From Cerveteri. Proto-Panaitian Group (Beazley){1}; Onesimos (Williams). Euphronios, potter. First quarter fifth. Ca. 500. 510-500 (Williams).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: youth starting a hare to run a race{2}. Ext.: komos: A: three youths, dancing. B: similar (fragmentary).
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: above the head and curving toward the hare: Λεαγρο(ς), retr.; to left of the youth's chest: κα[λ]ος, retr.{3}. Between the youth's feet (interrupted by the hare's foot): hο παις; and below: καλος{4}. A: [Λ]εαγρ̣[ο]ς κα[λ]ος{5}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Two frs. ex Leipzig; + a third fr., Leipzig. + Cambridge, MA, E.D.B. Vermeule (Guy). Ex Van Branteghem collection. Furtwängler and Hartwig attributed the cup to Euphronios; Beazley, to Proto-Panaitian; Williams (1976) to very early Onesimos.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Onesimos (Williams). {2} Beazley compares the kyathos Brussels A 2323, ARV[2] 333/2. {3} so the photo.; Williams gives the word complete. This is a sort of two-liner. {4} not a true two-liner. {5} so Williams' text. Is this a sort of two-liner also?
Record.AVI-Bibliography: C.H. Smith in BM Cat. E (1896), 71-72 (London only). — ARV[2] (1963), 315/1 (much bibl.). — D. Williams (1976), 16-17, figs. 8-10 (Int., A, B). — Add.[2] (1989), 213. — Bérard et al. (1989), 87, fig. 121 (a large colored picture of the Int., showing Λεαγρος and many other letters, but the layout is not clear to me, as some letters do not show). — D. Williams, CVA London 9, Great Britain 17 (1993), 15/2, pls. 203,fig. 4,b (profile) (much bibl.).

Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: an athlete at a laver. Ext.: athletes scraping themselves. A: two athletes.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A: to right of the left athlete's face: κονας{1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Louvre G 297 bis and other frs. Nearly complete.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} the dr. shows: --] vac. 2 /face/ κονας, but it need not be complete at left. Hence: [--]κονας or Κονας. This should be the athlete's name. See LGPN ii, s.v. Κοννᾶς.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Onesimos (O). First quarter fifth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: legs of a male. A: parts of two youths and a horse. B: a horse.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A: to right of the left youth's face: Λυκος. vac.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Two frs. + Louvre Cp 11,356 (ARV[2] 341/85, Antiphon Painter) joined with Louvre RS 457; Heidelberg 64 (ARV[2] 324/68) [[no inscr.]]; and Louvre RS 452. Lykos is listed as a kalos-name on this vase in ARV[2] 1595/5, but I wonder if there was a kalos; it could be the name of the youth. The above descriptions are based entirely on the two original Louvre frs.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: RF cup. From Naukratis. Onesimos (O). First quarter fifth. Ca. 490-480.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: a man (probably dictating) and a seated youth. A-B: school: fr. 3 (CVA, fig. 28): a bearded man playing the flutes{1}. A seated youth holds an open book roll. At right, a hand is writing with a stylus on open tablets. Another fr. (CVA, fig. 27) shows the left part of the exterior: an Ionic column; a nude youth, with a reticule, aryballos and strigil, leaning against it. Figs. 30 and 31: probably one man, perhaps a column at right.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: on one fr., maeander and ---]ος. Ext.: on the book roll, stoich. and boustr., starting left to right, in BG: στεσιχό|ρο̅ν hύμνο̅ν | ἄγοισαι{2}. Starting over the youth's head (fig. 27): hο παις κα[λος]{3}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Listed as Oxford G 138, 3, 5, 11 in ARV[2]. The book roll is on 3.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} perhaps trying it out (Beazley in CVA, after Winter). {2} so Beazley in AJA, after Herzog. [The meter is perhaps a dactyloepitrite, cf. Immerwahr (1964), 19, n. 3.] στεσίχορον hύμνον ἄγοισαι Beazley in CVA; supply [Μοῖσαι] at the beginning. {3} κα(λος) CVA, but probably broken at right (see JHS).
Record.AVI-Bibliography: BADB 203,345. — FR (1904–32), iii, 90 (after JHS, pl. 6,5). — Hogarth–Lorimer–Edgar (1905), pls. 6.5 (dr.) and 7,4 (photo). — Herzog (1912), 16/4. — J.D. Beazley, CVA Oxford 1, Great Britain 3 (1927), pl. 14, 27-31. — Beazley (1948), 337-8. — ARV[2] (1963), 326/93. — Immerwahr (1964), 19/2, fig. 1 (bibl.). — Para. (1971), 359. — Threatte (1980), 60. — Add.[2] (1989), 216. — AttScr (1990), no. 471. — Lissarrague (1990a), 136, fig. 105 (sketch of fr. with inscribed book roll).

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fr. of WG cup. From Athens. Manner of Onesimos (P). Euphronios, potter (?). Beginning fifth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int., WG: Struggle for the Tripod{1}.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: fr. a: along left margin: N[---]. Fr. b: similar, but bearing down: [--- κ]αλος{1}. Both inscriptions to be read from the outside.
Record.CAVI-Comments: = N.M. 15,191. Frs. a - b. - Robertson: "letters [sic] in the interior may be from Euphronios's name."{2}.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} see Gnomon 13, 290-91 (Beazley); Graef–Langlotz has a totally different explanation. {2} I interpreted this as N[--- κ]αλος, but this is quite uncertain.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fragmentary RF cup. From Vulci. Antiphon Painter. Euphronios, potter. First quarter fifth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: athlete pouring oil into his hand. At left, a pillar with a capital.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: Λ...{1}. On the athlete's right thigh {2} : Λαχες καλος. On the pillar, in three lines, aligned on left, down: hο παις | ναιχι | καλος{3}. On the VG fr., in field: Λ[---]. "Below"(4), Gr.: ΙΛ. Not in Johnston (1979).
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Villa Giulia. The Berlin part pared round and much restored.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} given in ARV[2]; see CF: perhaps Λ[αχες καλος](?). {2} "as if he were a statue," Beazley; similarly Furtw. Tiny letters, in BG(?). {3} so ARV[2]; Furtw. has καλ[ος]. I did not see the καλος in the photo. In BG? {4} so Furtw.; I do not know if under the foot or not.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Photo. — Gerhard (1848–50), pl. 13,5-6 (Berlin part). — Furtwängler (1885), pl. 3 (facs. of Gr.). — CF (1933), 34/19 (Villa Giulia part). — Blümel (1934), pl. 4 (Berlin part). — ARV[2] (1963), 336/14, 1646. — Add.[2] (1989), 218.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Orvieto. Antiphon Painter. First quarter fifth. Ca. 480 (Beazley).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: a youthful komast holding a skyphos and a flute case. Ext.: youths, boys and horses: Fr. a: parts of a horse; a Doric column. Fr. b: a heel(?), parts of a column base, and of a horse; foot. Fr. c: a left male leg; horse's legs, and a column base. Fr. d: a horse's head. Fr. e: a horse's head. Fr. f: parts of a horse and of a youth looking back (to left). Fr. g: a draped youth. Fr. i: a horse's tail to left; a hand holding a stick.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: to right of the youth's forehead: hο παις{1}. Fr. d: at right: [h]ο πα[ις ---]. Fr. f: at right: hο [---]. Fr. i: [καλο]ς h[ο παις](?).
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Viadana, Museo Civico, fr.: Boll. d'Arte 1974, 147ff., figs. 1-2 (facing p. 150): joining three of the Oxford frs. (Williams). The fr. increases the Int. and also the Ext.: I do not know what it does for the Ext. inscriptions. 8 frs. are illustrated in CVA, GB 3; one fr. is not ill. (Williams).
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} so the ph., pl. 13,1; not mentioned in Williams' text. [This is probably on the Viadana fr.].

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Manner of Antiphon Painter (Beazley); Pistoxenos Painter (Williams){1}. Second quarter fifth. Beginning fifth (Eichler).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: hoplitodromos(?): fr. a: greaved legs and a helmet held out (presumably held by the nose guard as in other pictures of hoplitodromoi). Fr. b: part of a shield seen sideways. Both frs. show parts of the maeander.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: starting to right of his waist, vertically down, nonsense (4 imitation letters show){2}. / Int.: fr. b: [h]ο π(α)ι[ς καλος].
Record.CAVI-Comments: 2 frs. in Vienna. + Leipzig T. 607. + Dresden AB 431. All joining. Alpha laccks the cross stroke.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Beazley att. the Vienna frs. and the fr. in Leipzig to the manner of the Antiphon Painter.; the Dresden fr. (giving the head) was unattributed. {2} so it seems from the photo, but Williams does not mention any inscription and I am not quite sure that these are letters. Eichler seems to have on one Vienna fr.: [h]ο π(α)ι[ς καλος], with alpha lacking the cross stroke.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: F. Eichler, CVA Vienna 1, Austria 1 (1951), pl. 5,5-6 (no bibl.). — ARV[2] (1963), 342/15 (Vienna), 343/29 (Leipzig). — D. Williams (1996), 244, fig. 12a-c (all frs. joined).

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fr. of RF cup. Antiphon Painter. First quarter fifth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: Amsterdam fr.: part of maeander border; right arm and hand stretched out to left. A Leipzig fr. has only the border. Amsterdam plus Leipzig frs.: Ext.: A: symposium: nude oinochoos (head missing) rushing to left; youth reclining to left holds out a cup, no doubt empty.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: Amsterdam fr.: between border and arm, roughly horizontal: Λυσι[ς ---]{1}. A: Leipzig T 3579: Λυσι[ς ---].(2)
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Leipzig T 3632 (ARV[2], no. 50) and T 3579 (no. 51). Combined by D. Williams. Amsterdam fr. ex Hauser, Arndt (no. 8185) and The Hagues, Scheurleer collections. - Most probably a kalos-name. - Hemelrijk says that Beazley's description in ARV[2] of his no. 51 `male in himation standing to left' suggests that there were more frs. [in Leipzig] when Beazley saw them.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} the Amsterdam fr.: see fig. 2 in Hemelrijk (1987) = ARV[2] 339/60. {2} Leipzig T 3579, according to ARV[2] 344/51.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: ARV[2] (1963), *339/60 (Amst., att. to Antiphon Ptr.), 344/50 (part) and *51 (2 Leipzig frs., both att. to manner of Antiphon Ptr.). — ARV[2] (1963), 339/60 and 344/50-51 (no bibl.). — Hemelrijk (1987), 4-5, figs. 1-2 (combination). — J.M. Hemelrijk, CVA Amsterdam 1, Netherlands 6 (1988), pl. 26,3-4 (composite phs. of Amst. + Leipzig frs; some letters show), figs. 24,a (dr., part of Amst. fr.) and 24,b (facs. of inscr. on Amst. fr.). — Add.[2] (1989), 218 (joins).

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Colmar Painter{1}. First quarter fifth. Early (Beazley).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: nude warrior seen from behind, with helmet, shield and lance. A-B: symposium.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: Α(ν)τι[α]ς, retr. καλος, κ(α)λος{2}. A: nonsense(?): αν(ρ)οκ(α) vac. ν(ο)(.){3}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Heidelberg 96 [[now in Dresden, no inscr. mentioned by Kraiker (1931)]]. + Leipzig T 522. + Tübingen E 12 + Dresden 305. + Braunschweig 538. + Amsterdam 2215. + Strasburg 848. ARV[2] (1963), 1643: the Tübingen, Heidelberg and Braunschweig frs. have been given to Dresden; the Amsterdam fr. joins Tübingen; an unpublished fr. in Florence probably also joins Tübingen.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} for the painter's connection with the wider circle of the Nikosthenes Painter, see ARV[2] 352 and 351. {2} so ARV[2]; ARV[1] does not say that these inscriptions are on the Int. The photo shows that they are. The nu reversed, one alpha without cross stroke: the letters of Antias are not properly retr. The dr. in AA 1977 (after DAI) shows a two-liner: between the warrior's legs, both lines bearing upward: h[ο] παις and καλος. The reading of the first line is uncertain [and no doubt wrong.] {3} the part before the vacat is on Tübingen, the other on Braunschweig; for the former, see the dr. in Watzinger, pl. 18. He thought that it was part of a signature of Pamphaios ([Π]ανφαιο[ς]), but this is rightly denied by Beazley, ARV[2] 1628, top. CVA, Germany 4, considers the inscription nonsense, but I wonder if there could be a name hidden in it: Αν[δ]ροκλ...(?).
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Photo (Int., part). — Photo DAI(R), neg. 75.704. — F. Hauser (1896), 186/27 (not ill.) [should be one of the frs., perhaps Leipzig T 522.]. — Watzinger (1924), pl. 18. — Beazley (1931), 46/23. — Kraiker (1931), pl. 13. — Kraiker (1931), pl. 13. — D. Levi, CVA Florence 1, Italy 8 (1932), pl. 11, B 22 (see CF). — D. Levi, CVA Florence 1, Italy 8 (1932), pls. 6 B 11 and 11 B 22. — CF (1933), ad pl. 11 B 22. — A. Greifenhagen, CVA Braunschweig, Germany 4 (1940), pl. 12,7 with text (Braunschweig and Dresden frs.). — ARV[1] (1942), 226/1. — ARV[2] (1963), 354/26, 1647. — Greifenhagen (1977), 232/55, fig. 59 (dr.; the Dresden fr.). — Immerwahr (1984), 352, bottom (on Tübingen fr., E 12, only). — Hemelrijk (1985), cover and pp. 1-3, figs. 1-3 (montage of parts). — J. Burow, CVA Tübingen 5, Germany 54 (1986), Beilage 1, fig. 2 (ph. of A, I do not know if all frs.; it includes the Tübingen fr.). — J.M. Hemelrijk, CVA Amsterdam 1, Netherlands 6 (1988), pl. 30,4 (composite of some frs. showing inscr. above head of reclining symposiast; it shows the inscription on the Tübingen fr. (probably continuing on the Braunschweig fr.); the bibl. on the frs. includes: Beazley (1951), CF (1933), CVA Braunschweig, Kraiker (1931), CVA Florence 1; 6 B 11 is a fr. mentioned by Hemelrijk which I had not previously included; he also mentions 2 more frs. in Florence, probably from Beazley (1951)). — Add.[2] (1989), 221.

Record.CAVI-Comments: + Florence (two frs.); Villa Giulia. - Similar: London 97.10-28.1, also by the Colmar Painter, ARV(2) 354/24; on B, while on A the inscription is [b] Λεαγρος[/b], retr.; the shields are both in profile: is that true of Heidelberg 95+? - This inscription ([b] καλος[/b]) seems common in the Colmar Painter.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Athens. Brygos Painter. First quarter fifth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Ext.: komos: fr. a: upper part of a bearded komast; stick of a companion. Fr.b: parts of two figures.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Fr. a: to left of komast's head: νανο̣[...]{1}. Fr. b: to left of leftperson's head: α̣νονεν{2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Frs. a - b. Typical Brygan nonsense (Peek's alphas may be gammas).
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Peek; Graef?Langlotz, text has νανε; dr. has νγνε̣[... {2} Peek, but hereads it retr. (νενονα̣), which is not likely. The dr. has: γνον(.)ε(ν), thefifth letter two little hooks, the last reversed. Peek thinks the inscriptionsare interjections and compares the BF Acr. 2184 and the RF 288.

Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: komast: a bearded man (with his mouth open); in the field. a lyre. [A second lyre on 677?]
Record.CAVI-Comments: + 677? Beazley says: two frs.; 587 and 677? Both numbers are listed with question marks in the index, but I think the query in the text refers only to 677. The problem of combining the two frs. is that de Ridder lists each as having a lyre in the Int. picture: were there two lyres?
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} is this one inscription, i.e. do the two frs. join?

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Manner of Brygos Painter; related to Castelgiorgio Painter. First quarter fifth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: arrival of a youth?{1}. A-B: Iliupersis: includes, on A, Neoptolemus seizing Priam by the arm, and, on B, Menelaus and Helen{2}.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Brygan nonsense: A: to right of a column: (γ)ν[--]{3}. Further: νν, να and ν{4}.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} so ARV[2]; not mentioned by de Ridder. Beazley says that the person greeting the youth may be male or female; he suggests Aegeus and Theseus and compares Louvre G 195, a very late skyphos by the Brygos Painter, ARV[2] 381/174. {2} de Ridder. {3} de Ridder suggests [Πρι]αμ[ος], which is highly unlikely. The gamma is disjointed. {4} so de Ridder in text. The inscriptions are probably all fragmentary.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Tarquinia. Unattributed. Brygos, potter. Ca. 500{1}.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: a seated deity and Nike. A-B: divinities.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: On the handle: Βρ̣[---]. On the foot: Βρυ[γος ---].
Record.CAVI-Comments: + 578, 580, and perhaps 722. The handle may not belong, but the foot no doubt does; the cup has no connection with the Brygos Painter (ARV[2]). See also AttScr (1990), 88, where I say that the handle should perhaps be detached. The rho is triangular.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} "much earlier than the other cups with the signature of Brygos," Beazley.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Orvieto. Makron. First quarter fifth. 490-480 (CVA). Hauptwerk II (Kunisch).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: feet and lower legs of a draped male. A: to right of the left handle: two bearded men (one fragmentary) and the foot of another figure are preserved{1}.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: On one handle, Gr.: hιερον εποιεσεν. [The sig. is a Gr. on the BG part of the right side of the handle. Direction: from the outside in.]
Record.CAVI-Comments: Ex Frankfurt, University. Done from the facs. Type B. Pi pinched in.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} ARV[2]: Int.: (male). A-B: (men, youth). Schaal has another fr., now lost, which probably joined at the left of the existing handle: youth.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Chiusi. Douris. Ca. 500. Very early.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: parts of a satyr holding a drinking horn. A: parts of a komos{1}.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: along the margin: [Χαιρε]στ[ρατος καλος].
Record.CAVI-Comments: V = Vagnonville. Two frs. The ph. in B.-O. shows the letters. Three-stroke sigma.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Beazley and B.-O. say A-B: komos, but it seems to me that the two frs. are both from A.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Douris. First quarter fifth. Period 1 (Beazley). Very early (Buitron-Oliver).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: a seated youth and a male with tablets. A-B: The Quarrel between Ajax and Odysseus over the arms of Achilles{2}.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: hο παι[ς καλ]ο[ς]. The photo, pl. 17 in B.-O., shows a fr. of the Ext. with the letters [--]πα[--] curving over the back and head of Ajax(?).
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Cab. Méd. 586 (parts), 597, 600, 727 (part), 774, L 224. The photo, pl. 17, shows a fr. of the Int. with a hand holding out open tablets.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} the inscriptions are not mentioned by B.-O. in her cat. {2} Guy.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: De Ridder (1902), ii, 453 (675 only; not ill.). — ARV[2] (1963), 428/14. — R. Guy apud D. Williams (1980), 139. — Robertson (1992), 88 and n. 275. — Buitron-Oliver (1995), 74/26, pl. 17{1}.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of WG cup. From Naukratis. Douris (Beazley); Onesimos (Williams){1}. First quarter fifth. Early (Beazley, Williams).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: WG: Europa and the bull. Ext.: WG: A: Struggle for the Tripod: Heracles (see below); at left, tip of a lance. B: fight.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: On the inside of the lip, Gr.: [---]ι α[---]. A: above the lance diagonally downward: hε[ρακλες], retr. [Απολλ]ον{2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: A Gr. dedication. - JHS 25, which has the inscription, is not figured in the earlier publications.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Hartwig attributed to Euphronios, Beazley to early Douris, Robertson to very early Douris (earlier than his WG lekythoi; affinity with Proto-Panaitian and Panaitian ), Williams to early Onesimos. {2} According to the information given to Beazley by Corbett, the fr. with this inscription was removed from the vase (see ARV[2] 1652 and below, London (ex D 1)), but Williams still gives it.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Gardner (1886), 52. — Smith (1888), 233. — C.H. Smith in BM Cat. E (1896), 388. — Hogarth–Lorimer–Edgar (1905), pl. 6,4 (one fr., dr.). — ARV[2] (1963), 429/20, 1652. — LIMC iv (1988), Europe I/37. — Add.[2] (1989), 236. — Robertson (1992), 55. — D. Williams, CVA London 9, Great Britain 17 (1993), 18/4, pl. 6, fig. 4,d (profile of lip).

Record.CAVI-Lemma: RF cup. From Vulci. Douris. Kleophrades, potter. Early fifth. 500-490.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: Nike and warrior. In the surrounding zone: chariot race. A-B: athletes.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: καλ[---, perhaps καλ[ε]{1}. In the zone: [hο] παις καλος. Παναιτιο[ς καλο]ς. A: ... καλ[ος], retr. B: Παναιτιος [κ]αλο[ς]. On the reserved foot profile, in BG: Κλε[ο]φρα[δες επο]ιεσε[ν].
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Vatican, Astarita 134 (now said to be in Berlin). The foot with its signature may go with Berlin 2283 or 2284 (Beazley (1933a)). All readings from ARV[2]; they seem to be Furtw.'s readings. According to Blösch, only a shadow of an alpha and two "punktförmige Reste" are now visible in the signature after a partial cleaning. παις is on the Astarita fragment. Furtw. reverses A and B; his facs. shows that the inscription on Beazley's B is not retr., as ARV[2] and B.-O. have it. - Panaitios: connected by Studniczka with the commander of a Tenian trireme that went over to the Greeks; Hdt. 8.82; see Studniczka, RE 1931, cols. 1002-1011. - For the interpretation of this and Berlin 2284 see Knauer (1996), 235. - Attic with four-stroke sigmas. Tailed rho in sig.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} B.-O. has καλος.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Vulci. Douris. Kleophrades, potter (?). Early fifth. 500-490.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: surround zone: chariot race. A-B: athletes (to left of handle, javelin thrower; to right of handle, two boxers).
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: in the zone: above the figures just below the rim, horizontal and widely spaced: Χαιρεστ[ρατος] κ[αλος]{1}. A: above: Δορις εγρα̣[φσεν].
Record.CAVI-Comments: Replica of Berlin 2283, q.v. The foot with the signature of Kleophrades may belong with Berlin 2283 or 2284 (Beazley (1933a)). Attic except sigma. Tailed rho.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: RF cup. Douris. Early fifth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: warrior. A-B: arming.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: to warrior's left: Δορις ε[γ]ραφσε, retr.{1}. A or B: κα[λο]ς{2}. Plus uncertain remains of letters{3}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Florence 11 B 39; Louvre C 11,388 (one fr.; ARV[2] 434/82 [attr. to Douris], Add.[2] 238); Louvre C 11,387 (ARV[2] 434/80 [attr. to Douris], Add.[2] 238); Louvre C 11,374 (part; ARV[2] 345/68 [attr. to manner of Antiphon Painter], Add.[2] 220); Louvre C 11,302 (ARV[2] 474/245 [attr. to Makron], Add.[2] 246 [misprinted in ref. to 434/82]). For the other two frs. of 11,388 see the CAVI entry under Louvre C 10,907.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} so CVA; εγραφσε, ARV[2]. {2} uncertain brackets; CVA has κα(λο)ς. {3} Louvre C 11,302, ARV[2] 474/245, has a male arm raised, with a stick, then an arm of another extended to the left; letter N or Μ. Louvre C 11,387 has, on the left of A, the letters: [--]ος (see ARV[2] 434/80). One fr. of Louvre C 11,374 has the letters [ναι]χι (see ARV[2] 345/68), but I do not know whether it belongs to this cup or to Louvre C 10,907.+
Record.AVI-Bibliography: D. Levi, CVA Florence 1, Italy 8 (1932), pl. 11, B 39 (Florence fr.). — A. Greifenhagen, CVA Bonn 1, Germany 1 (1938), pls. 4,1-2 and 5,1-2 (Bonn only). — ARV[2] (1963), 434/75. — Add.[2] (1989), 237. — Buitron-Oliver (1995), 80/123, pl. 75.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Douris. 480-470. Late period (B.-O.). *D. Buitron-Oliver, Douris (Kerameus 9, 1995) 85/223, pl. 110. ARV(2) 444/231, Add.(2)240.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: Upper part of a warrior in Thracian costume and with the pelta. Ext.: plain.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: to left and right of his head, along the rim: [b] [--]ς[/b] ^ [b] καλος[/b].(1)
Record.CAVI-Comments: = B 51. Two frs. added by Bothmer. B.-O. does not mention the inscription.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: (1)I do not see any trace of a letter before the first sigma; hence either [b] [[/b]h[b] ιπποδαμα]ς[/b] or [b] [[/b]h[b] ο παι]ς[/b].

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of WG cup. From Athens. Pistoxenos Painter. Ca. 480-470.
Record.CAVI-Subject: WG: Int.: Death of Orpheus. A, B: cavalrymen with horses.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: above Orpheus' head: Ορφευς. Γ[λαυκ]ον{1}. Above O.'s lyre, along the margin: [Ευφρονιος(?) επ]οιεσεν{2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: An unpublished fr. added by Karouzou is mentioned in JHS 64 (1944) 79. A small fr. in Athens with a black horse(?) may also belong. Robertson discusses the question of restoring Euphronios as the potter. New frs. are mentioned in BCH 76 (1952) 204. - I have a note from Philippaki's picture: Int.: below the axe held by the Thracian woman, bearing upward: [--]ο̣ν. Less than 1/2 of the omicron is preserved. Above the scene, curving along margin: [---]οιεσεν. Above Orpheus' head, horizontal but curving down at end: Ορφευς.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} so Graef–Langlotz; ARV[2] and the photo in Graef–Langlotz only show [---]ον. Doubtless had a καλος (Beazley). {2} see ARV[2] 859.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Graef–Langlotz (1925–33), ii, no. 439 (much bibl.), pls. 35,2 and 36. — ARV[2] (1963), 860/2 (much bibl.), 1672. — Para. (1971), 425. — Philippaki (1974), 100, fig. 44 (Int., good picture). — Mertens (1977), pl. 32,1-2 (Int., parts of A and B). — Add.[2] (1989), 298 (much bibl.). — Robertson (1992), 156-57. — Robertson (1992), 156-57.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF/WG cup. From Samos, Heraeum. Akin to Pistoxenos Painter{1}. Second quarter fifth. Ca. 470 (Technau).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: WG: Heracles. A: RF: youths.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: to left of Heracles' middle: [Αλκι]μαχ[ο]ς̣(?){2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Beazley says `akin to Pistoxenos Painter'; Robertson thinks probably by him. This might be Alkimachos son of Epichares, who appears as kalos on vases of this period; cf. ARV[2] 1561 and J.K. Davies (1971), 13. Very neat BG letters.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} the WG cups. {2} I thought I saw perhaps the tip of a final sigma in the photo.; Technau and Beazley do not give it.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Santa Barbara Painter (Beazley), near Ancona Painter and Painter of Palermo V 665 (Beazley). Second quarter fifth. 460 (Hemelrijk).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: head of youth to right, holding a hooked stick; head of boy (himation wrapped high) to left; betweem them, tablets tied up, with stylus; Ext.: men wooing women; Amsterdam 2831 preserves the lower part of a seated woman and a man (his upper part is Florence 24, ill. in CVA, Netherlands 6, pl. 44,1,b); also the lower part of another woman. Also ill. in pl. 44,,1,a, is Florence 23, with upper parts of a man and a woman. Amsterdam 2843, pl. 44,3, is the upper part of a man to left.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: above the head of the left youth, horizontal but slightly curved: καλ(ο)(ς){1}. Ext.: hο παις [---]. [The ext. inscr. not mentioned by Hemelrijk.]
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Amsterdam 2831 (published in CVA, Netherlands 6), + Florence 23, + Florence 24 (joins Amsterdam). The connections made by D. Williams. Amsterdam 2843 (CVA, Netherlands 6, pl. 44,3; ARV[2] (1963), 876/2) may also belong. The Florence frs. are said by Hemelrijk to be in Villa Giulia.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} the kalos is near the lefthand margin so something could have preceded it: [---] καλ(ο)(ς)(?).
Record.AVI-Bibliography: D. Levi, CVA Florence 1, Italy 8 (1932), III I, 14 B 17, 18, 23, 24. — CF (1933), 22 [not in Add.[2]] (Florence frs.). — ARV[2] (1963), 876/1 [14 B 17] (Florence frs.). — ARV[2] (1963), 876/1. — ARV[2] (1963), 876/3 (Amst.) [not in Add.[2]]. — J.M. Hemelrijk, CVA Amsterdam 1, Netherlands 6 (1988), pl. 44,1-2 (44,2 shows trace of inscr.), fig. 41 (facs. of inscr. on Amst. fr.).

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Ashby Painter. First quarter fifth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: a man (judge?) binding a young athlete with a fillet. A-B: athletes (parts).
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: [h]ο π[α]ις κα]λος{1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + four other frs.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} de Ridder (may be incomplete).

Decoration.Decoration-Description: DRAPED YOUTH LEANING ON STAFF, WOMAN, BLOCK (?) OR ROCK (?)
HERAKLES AND THE HYDRA BETWEEN ATHENA AND IOLAOS

Publication.Publication-Name: Lexicon Iconographicum Mythologiae Classicae
Beazley, J.D., Attic Red-Figure Vase-Painters, 2nd edition (Oxford, 1963)

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup-skyphos. From Athens, Agora E 14:5. Ashby Painter. Ca. 500 (Moore).
Record.CAVI-Subject: A: frs. a+b, d: Heracles and the Hydra; at left, Athena; at right, a small portion of Iolaus. B: subject unknown: fr. c: head and arm of a youth to left.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A: above Athena's aegis: κα[--]. In front of Heracles' chest: α[--]{1}. B: behind the youth's head and above his arm: [--]α[--].
Record.CAVI-Comments: Three frs.: a+b, c, d. [The letters are perhaps part of hο παις καλος.]
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} the beginning of this inscription was probably to left of the figure of Heracles: [--]α[--].
Record.AVI-Bibliography: ARV[2] (1963), 455/12. — LIMC v (1990), 36, Herakles 2008, pl. 55. — Moore (1997), 309/1340, pl. 125 (shows inscriptions).

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. From Athens, Agora K 13:1. Fauvel Painter. Ca. 420-410 (Moore).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: maeander. A: a youth leaving home: fr. a: upper part of a woman to left, with a phiale; at left, a hand to right. Fr. b: part of a (or the same?) woman and of a frontal man.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A: fr. a: above the woman: [κ]αλο[ς](?){1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Two frs.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} my guess. The sketch on p. 329 has αλο. Not visible in the ph. pl. 139.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Codrus Painter. Third quarter fifth. Ca. 430 (Beazley (1960a); Shapiro).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Unexplained subject: Shapiro: Helen and Paris? (Beazley thought, Birth of Aphrodite.) Fr. a: torso and head of an elderly Prometheus; Leda; Athena. Fr. b: the outstretched arm of Peitho beside a head with horns (Pan); two more frs. may have parts of the same figures. The American frs.: three more women's heads, including that of Timandra, daughter of Tyndareus and Leda.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Fr. a: upper part of a white-haired man, who is leaning on his stick. To right of his head: Προμεθ[ευς]{2}. Αθεν[αια]. Ληδα. Πειθω. US fr.: Timandra.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Four Astarita frs. + two formerly in an American private collection. Mixed alphabet.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} the entry needs correction. {2} so AJA 64; Προμε[θευς], ARV[2].

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fragmentary RF cup. Painter of London E 55 (Guy){1}. 480-470.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: a bearded man, seated; a youth facing him; between them, sponge, aryballos, and net bag. A-B: men and youths.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: hο παις καλ[ο]ς{2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: + Louvre S 1319 (ARV[2] 437/113). + Louvre C 11,457 (800/1). + New York, ex Bareiss [see B.-O., p. 114, list of illustrations], mentioned in Add.[2] 239 (under 437/113). The cup has not yet been put together.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} Beazley attributed two Louvre frs. to Douris and one (ARV[2] 800/1) to a follower. {2} so B.-O. in cat.; the photo shows καλ[ο]ς curving over the back and head of the seated man.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Epiktetos (Bothmer). Last quarter sixth. Ca. 510-500 (Bothmer).
Record.CAVI-Subject: A: upper portions of an archer and two warriors; that at right is bearded and carries a large shield (device, octopus).
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A: to right of the leftmost figure's head: [---]^εν{1}. On the shield, well centered above the octopus and following the curve of the shield rim, in BG: καλος.
Record.CAVI-Comments: = Malibu S.81.AE.1.3. Ex Bareiss 403.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} the missing portion would be to the left of the head. I read in the photo --]ες, but the sigma does not show clearly and Bothmer in the cat. is no doubt right in reading ]εν, which should be the end of a signature.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Manner of Epeleios Painter. Last quarter sixth.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Fr. a: to right of handle root: upper part of a youth to left, looking back; upper part of a youth bending over to right; tree. (Beazley says `athletes?' The cat. in Solothurn suggested a harvest.) Fr. b: middle part of a youth to right. Fr. c: handle.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Fr. a: between the heads and to right of the right head, perhaps traces (in the form of circles) of nonsense inscriptions.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Three frs., one a handle. Or Bolligen, Blatter? Listed as Berne, Private in AA. Para. lists the fr. as Roman Market.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Blatter (1967), 38f. (wrong attribution). — Para. (1971), 335 (fr. a only). — Blatter (1973a), 651-52, figs. 4-6.

Publication.Publication-Name: Beazley, J.D., Paralipomena (Oxford, 1971)

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Frs. of RF cup. Probably Manner of Epeleios Painter. Last quarter sixth. 510-500 (Cat.).
Record.CAVI-Subject: A: symposium: a standing girl playing the flutes, between two reclining figures (the couches are visible).
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: A: to left of her head: Ροδο̣π[ι](ς) [κα]λε, retr.{1}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Three frs.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} the omicron is 1/2 preserved, the iota is missing. Sigma is not reversed in retr. I thought the sigma possibly a reversed 4-stroke sigma, but I would doubt it.

Record.CAVI-Lemma: RF cup. Unattributed{1}. Ca. 500.
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: komos: a man with a lyre and a youth. A: Heracles and the Hydra. B: fight.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: hεκτ[ο]ρ καλος.
Record.CAVI-Comments: The same kalos-name is found, coupled with Leagros, on the contemporary cup, Copenhagen inv. 14268, perhaps by the Ashby Painter, ARV[2] 1583/2, 1654, Para. 506, Add.[2] (1989), 389, which is published better.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} recalls somewhat the Eleusis Painter and the Proto-Panaitian Group (Beazley). D. Williams, CVA, Great Britain 17, under number 7, attributes the cup to his Painter of London E 816.

Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum

Record.CAVI-Lemma: Fragmentary RF cup. Eretria Painter{1}. Third quarter fifth. 430 (Weiss).
Record.CAVI-Subject: Int.: two young athletes, that on the left with a javelin; that on the right holds out a scraper; at left, terma. A and B: small parts of several athletes.
Record.CAVI-Inscriptions: Int.: above and to right of the left youth: [κ]αλος. Under the foot, Gr.: ΑΜ(Α){2}.
Record.CAVI-Comments: Mixed alphabet. Ionic lambda. Three-stroke sigma.
Record.CAVI-Footnotes: {1} B. Otto, Weiss, Lezzi-Hafter. {2} Weiss apparently thinks that this is Etruscan; he cites Johnston (1979), p. 32. The last letter need not be an alpha: it looks more like a rho in the facs.
Record.AVI-Bibliography: Lezzi-Hafter (1988), 357, cat. XVI 72 (no other bibl. in CVA). — C. Weiss, CVA Karlsruhe 3, Germany 60 (1990), pl. 37,1-7, fig. 21 (profile); p. 75, facs. of Gr. and dr. of part of Int. with inscription.
